It uses WebKit under the hood, and boasts features such as private search, tracker blocking, automatic cookie pop-up management (yes please) andÂ more.

Beah Burger-Lenehan (DuckDuckGo)

Boost Resource Loading With fetchpriority, a New PriorityÂ Hint â€” The new attribute helps us fine-tune relative resource priority, improve LCP performance, and deprioritize JavaScript fetch calls. This post digs into some potential useÂ cases.

Adrian Bece

How to Build a Fullstack App from Scratch â€” Join Scott Moss for this detailed course looking at modern app building. Get to grips with a stack of tools, including the likes of Next.js, TypeScript, Postgres, and React, plus you'll learn about data modeling, authentication, state management, testing andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Designing Better Breadcrumb-Based Navigation â€” Explores how people navigate websites and how this prominent design pattern can assist us in ourÂ journeys.

Vitaly Friedman

Luca Falasco

items.content:
Frontend Focus

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ #â€‹536 â€” April 6, 2022 | Read on the web

Tweaking in the Browser? â€” Some well-reasoned thoughts here on the nuance behind designing in the browser and how it often results in a process of constant context switching and tweaking. Ahmad goes on to share his approach, and the place design tools like Figma have in hisÂ workflow.

Ahmad Shadeed

Designing a Better Infinite Scroll â€” There are a lot of considerations when it comes to implementing a sound, user friendly infinite scroll. This article digs in to them (pagination, load more, URL changes on scroll, footer reveal, etc), with plenty of visual examplesÂ too.

Vitaly Friedman

Filestack: The Premier File Handling Service â€” Filestack is the all-in-one solution for your file handling needs, from blazing fast uploads to swift, reliable, delivery. Take advantage of image intelligence features like optical character recognition or object tagging to level up your appÂ today.

Filestack sponsor

Accessible Description Exposure â€” A helpful bit of work from Adrian here, digging into how aria-describedby is exposed across a half dozen screen readers and browsers. Lots of videos showing how things vary. The takeaway: â€œDefinitely do not rely on the accessible description to convey criticalÂ informationâ€.

Adrian Roselli

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Devs for Ukraine ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ is an online charity conference taking place later this month. A fantastic initiative.
  • This post from Rachel Andrew outlines some of the interesting features that landed in stable and beta web browsers during March 2022.
  • The CSS Media Queries specification is now 20 years old â€”Â the first draft was released on April 4th, 2001.
  • Did you know if you use Twitter's JavaScript embed and the tweet in question then gets deleted it's also removed from your site?
  • What's the impact of removing jQuery from a site with millions of users? Here's some real-world data on just that from the UK government.
  • Aakash Rao has put together these handy CSS cheatsheets, covering flexbox, animations, selectors, CSS units, and more.

A Guide to Hover and Pointer Media Queries â€” Food for thought here on how to adapt your sites to the various scenarios of a device pointer, plus a look at how to go about properly using media queries such as hover, pointer, any-hover and any-pointer toÂ help.

Cristian Diaz

Building an Interactive Sparkline Graph withÂ D3 â€” Goes into a lot of implementation depth â€“ a good tutorial.

Michelle Barker

How To Build a Progressively Enhanced, Accessible, Filterable and Paginated List â€” Ever wondered how to build a paginated list that works with and without JavaScript? This article explains just how you can leverage progressive enhancement to do just that with Eleventy andÂ Alpine.js.

Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡

Locate Front-End Issues on Web Applications in Real-Time with Datadog â€” Identify and resolve front-end issues on your web applications before your customers notice. Start a free trialÂ today.

Datadog Real User Monitoring sponsor

Performance Tool in Firefox DevTools Reloaded â€” Version 98 of Firefox features a new version of the â€˜Performanceâ€™ panel in the DevTools Toolbox. Hereâ€™s a quick look at how to useÂ it.

Jan Honza Odvarko, Nicolas Chevobbe (Mozilla)

Optimizing Core Web Vitals on SPAs â€” Single-page applications often present some unique challenges for measuring and optimizing core web vitals â€” hereâ€™s a review of some key optimisations you should be making forÂ yours.

Simon Hearne

Draw 'Handdrawn' Diagrams in VS Code with Excalidraw â€” Excalidraw is a popular online drawing tool for creating â€˜hand drawnâ€™ diagrams, and one of its coolest features is being able to export in SVG for lossless use in your pages. This VS Code extension brings it.. well, into VS Code, and is now blessed as being the official VS Code ExcalidrawÂ extension.

Visual Studio Marketplace / Achille Lacoin

a11y-dialog: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs â€” Itâ€™s possible to replace JS dialogs with the <dialog> element in many cases now, but thatâ€™s not always desired. This is a nice implementation â€“ demo.

Kitty Giraudel

Porkbun.com. The Best Home for Your Next Online Project. Start Today

Porkbun.com sponsor

Martian Mono: An Open-Source Monospace Type Family â€” Consisting of a variable font and 28 styles. Contains only basic Latin, figures, punctuation, and essential symbols right now, but ligatures for code, italics, and other language support are said to be inÂ progress.

Evil Martians

pppalette: A Friendly Color Palette Generator for Beautiful Colors â€” Another useful tool from SÃ©bastien, this one to generate different color palettes, and optionally choose a color to use with various blending options for a more cohesiveÂ palette.

SÃ©bastien NoÃ«l

Snipt: A Code Snippet Search Engine â€” Search code snippets from 15+ programming languages, sourced from code snippets created in various ways using the Codiga code snippetÂ service. Of course, the first thing I tried was centering an item with CSS.. and it workedÂ :-)

codiga

Detergent: An Online Tool to Prepare Text for Pasting into HTML â€” Text should be HTML-encoded, have no invisible characters, use smart characters where possible.. things like that.

Codsen

Six Useful Browser Bookmarklets to Boost Web Development
Daniel Schwarz

ğŸ’Œ Our Other Newsletters

Beyond Frontend Focus we also publish a handful of other helpful email newsletters that you might not know about. You can see the latest issues of each directly on theirÂ homepages:

ğŸ’› JavaScript Weekly, as you might expect, covers all things JavaScript and the wider JS ecosystem, including TypeScript, WebAssembly, Vue.js, and more.

âš›ï¸ React Status dives into the the React and React Native world, whereas Node Weekly goes deeper on all things Node.js, the npm ecosystem, and other server-side JS platforms like Deno.

âš¡ï¸ Serverless Status focuses entirely on serverless platforms, the idea of functions as a service, and the increasing number of new places serverless ideas keep popping up.

ğŸ“ JAMstacked is Brian Rinaldi's fortnightly update on the quickly evolving JAMstack ecosystem.

ğŸ˜ Both Postgres Weekly and Go(lang) Weekly round out our collection (hopefully it's obvious what they're about). I hope you'll take a look and find something of interest :-)

Understanding Layout Algorithms â€” Another great article from Josh â€” this time going beyond focusing on individual properties, instead taking a higher-level look at CSS, how it's structured, and how to form a solid mental model for using it.

Josh W. Comeau

Chrome Version 100 Arrives (with Refreshed Logo in Tow) â€” 14 years after its debut, Googleâ€™s browser hits triple digits with Chrome 100. There's also a timeline of 100 cool wider web moments, looking at neat events from throughout Chrome's lifetime.

Jon Porter

ğŸ¨Â Â Who here remembers the Chrome comic Google published back in 2008 explaining how their take on the browser would work?

Dominate Your Lighthouse Score in Next.js Applications â€” Developers take care of onsite SEO now more than ever - see how to lay the perfect foundation and keep your Lighthouse score in Next.js applications at its peak. Click here to make sure all your boxes areÂ checked.

The Software House sponsor

Those HTML Attributes You Never Use â€” Describes and demonstrates some interesting HTML attributes that you may or may not have heard of and perhaps find useful enough to personally use in one of yourÂ projects.

Louis Lazaris

Mozillaâ€™s Vision for the Evolution of the Web â€” Mozilla has outlined its vision of the future of the web, based on three values: openness, agency, and safety. In practice the hope is this is a web that's encrypted by default, has better accessibility and internationalization, and no tracking. You can read a summary here if youâ€™d rather not read the fullÂ post.

â€œThe Web is an enormous asset to humanity and Mozilla is committed to protecting it and making it better. [..] we believe that we can all work together as a community to make a Web that is truly open and accessible to all.â€

___
Mozilla

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Noel Rappin's new book, due out in July (but in beta now), looks at writing modern CSS with Tailwind 3.0.
  • Here's a trip down memory lane, looking at how the UI/UX of Firefox has changed over the past near 20 years.
  • Jen Simmons of the Webkit team asks what tech shipping this year developers are looking forward to use (and what seems overwhelming).
  • Google has issued an emergency security update for Chrome version 99.0.4844.84 to fix a serious security vulnerability.

Roman Shamin & Travis Tuner

Scott Vandehey

Tired of Asking Users to Enter Passwords in Your Applications? â€” Check out our blog post on how you can easily integrate magic links in your React chat apps withÂ Supabase.

Stream sponsor

David Walsh

The Web as the Ultimate Tool of Resilience for the World? â€” Marking two years since the start of the pandemic, W3C CEO Jeff Jaffe reflects on how the web became the 'ultimate tool of resilience' for theÂ world.

Jeff Jaffe (W3C)
